text: Hi everyone, I’m hiring a managing editor for our blog - what are some great recruitment exercises you’ve seen for testing a candidate’s ability to manage a blog? Most of the time people are asked to ‘come up with blog post ideas’ or ‘write a short article’ to test their writing skills but how would you test blog management skills? and also SEO knowledge?

elements.text: Hi everyone, I’m hiring a managing editor for our blog - what are some great recruitment exercises you’ve seen for testing a candidate’s ability to manage a blog? Most of the time people are asked to ‘come up with blog post ideas’ or ‘write a short article’ to test their writing skills but how would you test blog management skills? and also SEO knowledge?

text:
I'd ask them to create a plan for e.g. next quarter having a mix of some 3-5 topic clusters (for example 4 blog post each month). That would test their content management.

As for SEO knowledge -- it's always worth to check how someone would rank for chosen keyword, having (hypothetically) 0 content at the moment for this keyword.

elements.text:
I'd ask them to create a plan for e.g. next quarter having a mix of some 3-5 topic clusters (for example 4 blog post each month). That would test their content management.

As for SEO knowledge -- it's always worth to check how someone would rank for chosen keyword, having (hypothetically) 0 content at the moment for this keyword.

text:
I think it depends on what the job actually entails; for example: (edited)

• if you expect them to manage freelancers, you could ask for a workflow suggestion
• if you expect them to oversee SEO, you could ask them to walk you through how they'd research an outline to cover keyword/cluster [x}
• and so on. :slightly_smiling_face: 
I'll DM you for more details!

elements.text: I think it depends on what the job actually entails; for example: (edited)
if you expect them to manage freelancers, you could ask for a workflow suggestion
if you expect them to oversee SEO, you could ask them to walk you through how they'd research an outline to cover keyword/cluster [x}
and so on.
I'll DM you for more details!

text: I've found that asking them to walk me through how a blog post gets published from start to finished  really gives me a good idea of their ability. You could ask this during the interview or have it be an exercise (giving a word count/guideline). This is where I see people give super detailed answers (going over research, SEO, review process, etc.) and then people who have a 30-second answer that's generic.

elements.text: I've found that asking them to walk me through how a blog post gets published from start to finished  really gives me a good idea of their ability. You could ask this during the interview or have it be an exercise (giving a word count/guideline). This is where I see people give super detailed answers (going over research, SEO, review process, etc.) and then people who have a 30-second answer that's generic.

text: RE: both SEO and general content creation/mgmt -- I'd recommend asking them questions about how they'd define the audience for the content and how they'd understand what's important to that audience so the content resonates. Also if they're sharper with SEO, they should understand how a piece of content may or may not succeed with Google based on the intent of the search query and the content they're creating (articles vs landing pages vs FAQ pages vs listicles vs tools etc).

elements.text: RE: both SEO and general content creation/mgmt -- I'd recommend asking them questions about how they'd define the audience for the content and how they'd understand what's important to that audience so the content resonates. Also if they're sharper with SEO, they should understand how a piece of content may or may not succeed with Google based on the intent of the search query and the content they're creating (articles vs landing pages vs FAQ pages vs listicles vs tools etc).

text: I've given an exercise where I provide a topic/keyword and ask the candidate to write a detailed brief around it (as if they were assigning it).

elements.text: I've given an exercise where I provide a topic/keyword and ask the candidate to write a detailed brief around it (as if they were assigning it).

text: Hi all — wondering if any of you (or content people you know) have made a switch into product marketing? I know responsibilities vary a bit position to position, but the messaging and positioning aspects seem really in line with content marketing skills. Thoughts? Experience? I mean, what is life after content marketing?

elements.text: Hi all — wondering if any of you (or content people you know) have made a switch into product marketing? I know responsibilities vary a bit position to position, but the messaging and positioning aspects seem really in line with content marketing skills. Thoughts? Experience? I mean, what is life after content marketing?

text: Following because I’m interested in others’ thoughts on this, too! :eyes:

elements.text: Following because I’m interested in others’ thoughts on this, too!

text:
I did a quick (i mean like, super quick) foray into product marketing when ours left our company and we had a huge product launch coming up. (Plus, the role I was in was likely to be collapsed.)
 I liked the messaging, positioning and planning launches. I hated the rest of the work--research, capturing customer feedback, thinking about pricing, doing technical implementation decks/teaching…so that’s worth thinking through :stuck_out_tongue:
I think life after content marketing is hopefully director or VP of all marketing if you can get enough breadth and depth to do it--maybe being a product marketer will help you get there.

elements.text:
I did a quick (i mean like, super quick) foray into product marketing when ours left our company and we had a huge product launch coming up. (Plus, the role I was in was likely to be collapsed.)
 I liked the messaging, positioning and planning launches. I hated the rest of the work--research, capturing customer feedback, thinking about pricing, doing technical implementation decks/teaching…so that’s worth thinking through
I think life after content marketing is hopefully director or VP of all marketing if you can get enough breadth and depth to do it--maybe being a product marketer will help you get there.

text: One of the things I see a lot, particularly from technical co-founders at our clients, is concern about search intents (and thus blog posts) being "too basic" at the top of their funnels.  I've found a great way to appease all parties is to publish those to /glossary or /library so that, when the content goes live, you can advertise it as "we just added {techie thing 101} to our library or "we just added {simple techie definition} to our glossary."  Then more thought-leadership-y/middle of the funnel content goes under /blog

elements.text: One of the things I see a lot, particularly from technical co-founders at our clients, is concern about search intents (and thus blog posts) being "too basic" at the top of their funnels. Then more thought-leadership-y/middle of the funnel content goes under /blog

text: So, tl;dr /blog for thought leadership /glossary or /library for educational search intents

text: Hi all! A client (B2B, shipping/supply chain) has recently posed me this question, "Should we invest heavily into SEO?" This is unlike any other SEO project I had where normally, they already want to do SEO of some kind. I also looked into their competitors - none of them do any. This industry has its search terms dominated by consulting companies, interestingly. There is definitely an opportunity if nobody is doing it right now, but the largest competitors could also have deemed that it is not worth the trouble/tried it before and didn't work and would rather focus on ABM strategies (which they are already doing). How would you go about answering this question? I've done quite an indepth research on the search landscape in question and I can confirm that there isn't any precedence. I have some ideas but love to hear opinions too :)

elements.text: Hi all! A client (B2B, shipping/supply chain) has recently posed me this question, "Should we invest heavily into SEO?" This is unlike any other SEO project I had where normally, they already want to do SEO of some kind. I also looked into their competitors - none of them do any. This industry has its search terms dominated by consulting companies, interestingly. There is definitely an opportunity if nobody is doing it right now, but the largest competitors could also have deemed that it is not worth the trouble/tried it before and didn't work and would rather focus on ABM strategies (which they are already doing). How would you go about answering this question? I've done quite an indepth research on the search landscape in question and I can confirm that there isn't any precedence. I have some ideas but love to hear opinions too :)

text: One of the first things I'd look at is attempting to quantify the value of the current search traffic. Barring that, web traffic in general. If the property that's the target of any SEO can demonstrate that it makes money (either directly on indirectly), then there's a math-path to gauging out a potential investment. For example, I client I work with doesn't have any nice funnels set up but will tell you the time they booked a $20k job from their web form. From there, what % of web form inquiries convert (guesstimate if you have you) * average sale amount = value of one lead. Work from there to estimate what % of organic traffic could convert to a lead.

elements.text: One of the first things I'd look at is attempting to quantify the value of the current search traffic. Barring that, web traffic in general. If the property that's the target of any SEO can demonstrate that it makes money (either directly on indirectly), then there's a math-path to gauging out a potential investment. For example, I client I work with doesn't have any nice funnels set up but will tell you the time they booked a $20k job from their web form. From there, what % of web form inquiries convert (guesstimate if you have you) * average sale amount = value of one lead. Work from there to estimate what % of organic traffic could convert to a lead.

text: I'd try to walk it to ROI with some back-of-the-napkin math.  Ballpark, for this amount of money, we could probably get X monthly traffic.  The traffic would become leads at Y%, and the value of a lead would be $Z.

elements.text: I'd try to walk it to ROI with some back-of-the-napkin math.  Ballpark, for this amount of money, we could probably get X monthly traffic.  The traffic would become leads at Y%, and the value of a lead would be $Z.

text: The nice thing about that with a prospect or client is that it's kind of a tracer bullet at the discussion.  If they leap to argue with you about one of the variables, that's actually progress because it's discovery for you and, on some level, they're buying into the reasoning.

elements.text: The nice thing about that with a prospect or client is that it's kind of a tracer bullet at the discussion.  If they leap to argue with you about one of the variables, that's actually progress because it's discovery for you and, on some level, they're buying into the reasoning.

text: (As an aside, I'd personally be leery of engaging with a client for a service of which they're skeptical, and probably try to do a light form of disqualification in the account management.  IOW, you have what I think of as a "2 sale" problem, where you have to convince them first that SEO is a valid approach, and secondarily to invest money in it.  That's a recipe for client micromanagement and nerves and pulling the plug before the process has had a chance to work.  Not saying that will be the case in your situation, specifically, but it's a lot more likely than if a client was enthusiastically clamoring for SEO)

elements.text: (As an aside, I'd personally be leery of engaging with a client for a service of which they're skeptical, and probably try to do a light form of disqualification in the account management.  IOW, you have what I think of as a "2 sale" problem, where you have to convince them first that SEO is a valid approach, and secondarily to invest money in it.  That's a recipe for client micromanagement and nerves and pulling the plug before the process has had a chance to work.  Not saying that will be the case in your situation, specifically, but it's a lot more likely than if a client was enthusiastically clamoring for SEO)

text: Thanks <@U01AHL8AGBB> Good point - it reminds me I should look at the GA to get a sense of their user flow from various channels. Trouble is, when someone fills in a form then the long sales cycle begins from qualification, in person visits, down to sales which takes months and humans. It does not seem that they have it tracked well, yet. Some social campaigns seem to be generating interest though, so I suppose that web traffic as a whole could be used instead of a singular channel as they have to bypass the form anyway.

text:
:wave:  Hey everyone, I’m curious if anyone works for an in-house content team for a SaaS company and are *using scrum for your content workflow*? If ya, would you mind sharing how it works where you are and what you love/hate about it?  If no, does anyone have general thoughts on scrum for content?

*Spoiler alert*: I don’t agree with the methodology for a content team bc I think content is more of a long game and prefer to do my planning in quarterly roadmaps with longer turnaround for retrospectives BUT I _am_ looking to be convinced otherwise and want to hear from folks with experience on this!

hmu in the thread and thanks in advance :pray:

text:
Most Upwork content marketing jobs are cheap and difficult to win (especially considering the prices that other Upwork freelancers are offering).

Actually searching out companies in a niche and researching them and pitching them would result in better customers and pay. (And would take about as long)

Pick an industry and search them out on linkedin, and then reach out to them over the phone/email with a personalized pitch.

elements.text:

Actually searching out companies in a niche and researching them and pitching them would result in better customers and pay. (And would take about as long)

Pick an industry and search them out on linkedin, and then reach out to them over the phone/email with a personalized pitch.

text:
I've done scrum before and I've done content, but have never mixed the two. The creative in me shudders at the idea of daily standups and sprints being applied to my writing work... but the executor in me can see how the approach might be invigorating for a high output team with a LOT in the pipeline.

My gut says that a scrum approach could be a great in high concentration doses followed by generous decompression periods. Like, do two sprints to populate that 150 page website that the client wants done ASAP... but if you've two of those back to back to tackle at least cycle the creatives out on a regular basis? Hm.

`/me subscribes to this thread`

text:
:wave:  Hey Allison, I was literally just on <https://www.ryrob.com/freelance-jobs/|this page> today which is the long answer.

I have to agree with Patrick above though. Outbounding and pitching your services to clients you want to work with helps you define what you want to specialize in and get good at.

Also, once you wrap up a job done well, don’t just call it a day! Word of mouth referrals are powerful. Ask your clients if they know anyone who might need your services and to send them your way if anything comes up. Networking over time is like compound interest and yields you a return over time! Hope that helps and good luck :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I spent a lot of years running software teams/departments that used Scrum, or a flavor thereof, as the development approach to create software.  It's really hard for me to see how (or why) it translates from reducing risk in custom app dev to doing... anything... in something much more clearly defined, like content creation.

elements.text: I spent a lot of years running software teams/departments that used Scrum, or a flavor thereof, as the development approach to create software.  It's really hard for me to see how (or why) it translates from reducing risk in custom app dev to doing... anything... in something much more clearly defined, like content creation.

text: (I'd be happy to elaborate on why I think this re-appropriation is so odd, but it'd be a pretty significant diversion into the original motivations for Scrum as a methodology and what developing software used to be like a couple of decades ago, so I don't want to derail the thread)

text: A fast way to test the channel would be Google ads + lead magnet.  If you can get people to download a pdf or whitepaper that can be considered a warm prospect.  If they agree with that then apply the Adwords conversion rate to the kw volume of your PPC terms to get an rough estimate of the max # of leads they could acquire organically (i.e. ranking #1 for most of the terms).

elements.text: A fast way to test the channel would be Google ads + lead magnet.  If you can get people to download a pdf or whitepaper that can be considered a warm prospect.  If they agree with that then apply the Adwords conversion rate to the kw volume of your PPC terms to get an rough estimate of the max # of leads they could acquire organically (i.e. ranking #1 for most of the terms).

text: Also, IMHO, if competitors in a high LTV industry are not doing any seo it means they are dumb, not that they've decided it was not worth it.  :slightly_smiling_face:   Showing up on page 1 = branding and positioning which will grease the rest of the sales process.

text:
We use bits of scrum and apply it to content. We’re a small in-house team. We work with one week sprints and have a basic pipeline of: todo, in progress and done. We have a weekly meeting to discuss the sprint and we do sprint grooming and planning before the start of the new sprint. It works well, better than before when we just planned a boat load of things to work on in a massive spreadsheet.

Reason: we need to be flexible as we’re in a dynamic industry (SEO) so often times we’ll change plans along the way, while still hitting our larger goals of course.
